member.name: T:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands
member.summary: Used by the user32.GetWindow function See GetWindow function The relationship between the specified window and the window whose handle is to be retrieved. This parameter can be one of the following values.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDFIRST
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is highest in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDLAST
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window of the same type that is lowest in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDNEXT
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window below the specified window in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands.GW_HWNDPREV
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the window above the specified window in the Z order. If the specified window is a topmost window, the handle identifies a topmost window. If the specified window is a top-level window, the handle identifies a top-level window. If the specified window is a child window, the handle identifies a sibling window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands.GW_OWNER
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the specified window's owner window, if any. For more information, see Owned Windows: An overlapped or pop-up window can be owned by another overlapped or pop-up window. Being owned places several constraints on a window. An owned window is always above its owner in the z-order. The system automatically destroys an owned window when its owner is destroyed. An owned window is hidden when its owner is minimized. Only an overlapped or pop-up window can be an owner window; a child window cannot be an owner window. An application creates an owned window by specifying the owner's window handle as the hwndParent parameter of CreateWindowEx when it creates a window with the WS_OVERLAPPED or WS_POPUP style. The hwndParent parameter must identify an overlapped or pop-up window. If hwndParent identifies a child window, the system assigns ownership to the top-level parent window of the child window. After creating an owned window, an application cannot transfer ownership of the window to another window. Dialog boxes and message boxes are owned windows by default. An application specifies the owner window when calling a function that creates a dialog box or message box. An application can use the GetWindow function with the GW_OWNER flag to retrieve a handle to a window's owner.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands.GW_CHILD
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the child window at the top of the Z order, if the specified window is a parent window; otherwise, the retrieved handle is NULL. The function examines only child windows of the specified window. It does not examine descendant windows.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.GetWindowCommands.GW_ENABLEDPOPUP
member.summary: The retrieved handle identifies the enabled popup window owned by the specified window (the search uses the first such window found using GW_HWNDNEXT); otherwise, if there are no enabled popup windows, the retrieved handle is that of the specified window.

member.name: T:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates
member.summary: See here

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_NORMAL
member.summary: Indicates that the object does not have another state assigned to it.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_UNAVAILABLE
member.summary: The object is unavailable.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_SELECTED
member.summary: The object is selected.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_FOCUSED
member.summary: The object has the keyboard focus. Do not confuse object focus with object selection. For more information, see Selection and Focus Properties and Methods. For objects with this object state, send the EVENT_OBJECT_SHOW or EVENT_OBJECT_HIDE WinEvents to notify client applications about state changes. Do not use EVENT_OBJECT_STATECHANGE.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_PRESSED
member.summary: The object is pressed.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_CHECKED
member.summary: The object's check box is selected.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_MIXED
member.summary: Indicates that the state of a three-state check box or toolbar button is not determined. The check box is neither selected nor cleared and is therefore in the third or mixed state.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_INDETERMINATE
member.summary: Same as STATE_SYSTEM_MIXED

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_READONLY
member.summary: The object is designated read-only.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_HOTTRACKED
member.summary: The object is hot-tracked by the mouse, which means that the object's appearance has changed to indicate that the mouse pointer is located over it.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_DEFAULT
member.summary: This state represents the default button in a window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_EXPANDED
member.summary: The object's children that have the ROLE_SYSTEM_OUTLINEITEM role are displayed.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_COLLAPSED
member.summary: The object's children that have the ROLE_SYSTEM_OUTLINEITEM role are hidden.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_BUSY
member.summary: The control cannot accept input at this time.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_FLOATING
member.summary: The object is not clipped to the boundary of its parent object, and it does not move automatically when the parent moves.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_MARQUEED
member.summary: Indicates scrolling or moving text or graphics.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_ANIMATED
member.summary: The object's appearance changes rapidly or constantly. Graphics that are animated occasionally are described as ROLE_SYSTEM_GRAPHIC with the State property set to STATE_SYSTEM_ANIMATED. This state is used to indicate that the object's location is changing.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_INVISIBLE
member.summary: The object is programmatically hidden. For example, menu itmes are programmatically hidden until a user activates the menu. Because objects with this state are not available to users, client applications must not communicate information about the object to users. However, if client applications find an object with this state, they should check whether STATE_SYSTEM_OFFSCREEN is also set. If this second state is defined, clients can communicate the information about the object to users. For example, a list box can have both STATE_SYSTEM_INVISIBLE and STATE_SYSTEM_OFFSCREEN set. In this case, the client application can communicate all items in the list to users. If a client application is navigating through an IAccessible tree and encounters a parent object that is invisible, Microsoft Active Accessibility will not expose information about any possible children of the parent as long as the parent is invisible.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_OFFSCREEN
member.summary: The object is clipped or has scrolled out of view, but it is not programmatically hidden. If the user makes the viewport larger, more of the object will be visible on the computer screen.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_SIZEABLE
member.summary: The object can be resized. For example, a user could change the size of a window by dragging it by the border.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_MOVEABLE
member.summary: Indicates that the object can be moved. For example, a user can click the object's title bar and drag the object to a new location.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_SELFVOICING
member.summary: The object or child uses text-to-speech (TTS) technology for description purposes. When an object with this state has the focus, a speech-based accessibility aid does not announce information because the object automatically announces it.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_FOCUSABLE
member.summary: The object is on the active window and is ready to receive keyboard focus.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_SELECTABLE
member.summary: The object accepts selection.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_LINKED
member.summary: Indicates that the object is formatted as a hyperlink. The object's role will usually be ROLE_SYSTEM_TEXT.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_TRAVERSED
member.summary: The object is a hyperlink that has been visited (previously clicked) by a user.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_MULTISELECTABLE
member.summary: Indicates that the object accepts multiple selected items; that is, SELFLAG_ADDSELECTION for the IAccessible::accSelect method is valid.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_EXTSELECTABLE
member.summary: Indicates that an object extends its selection by using SELFLAG_EXTENDSELECTION in the IAccessible::accSelect method.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_ALERT_LOW
member.summary: Indicates low-priority information that is not important to the user. This state is used, for example, when Word changes the appearance of the TipWizard button on its toolbar to indicate that it has a hint for the user.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_ALERT_MEDIUM
member.summary: Indicates important information that is not conveyed immediately to the user. For example, when a battery is starting to reach a low level, a level indicator generates a medium-level alert. A blind access tool then generates a sound to let the user know that important information is available, without actually interrupting the user's work. The user could then query the alert information when convenient.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_ALERT_HIGH
member.summary: Indicates important information to be immediately conveyed to the user. For example, when a battery reaches a critically low level, a level indicator generates a high-level alert. As a result, a blind access tool immediately announces this information to the user, and a screen magnification program scrolls the screen so that the battery indicator is in view. This state is also appropriate for any prompt or operation that must be completed before the user can continue.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_PROTECTED
member.summary: The object is a password-protected edit control.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_HASPOPUP
member.summary: When invoked, the object displays a pop-up menu or a window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ObjectStates.STATE_SYSTEM_VALID
member.summary: A bitmask representing all valid state flags

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ShowWindowCommands.Restore
member.summary: Activates and displays the window. If the window is minimized or maximized, the system restores it to its original size and position. An application should specify this flag when restoring a minimized window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ShowWindowCommands.ShowDefault
member.summary: Sets the show state based on the SW_* value specified in the STARTUPINFO structure passed to the CreateProcess function by the program that started the application.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ShowWindowCommands.ForceMinimize
member.summary: Windows 2000/XP: Minimizes a window, even if the thread that owns the window is not responding. This flag should only be used when minimizing windows from a different thread.

member.name: T:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags
member.summary: See Extended Window Styles

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_NONE
member.summary: Default style, with nothing

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_DLGMODALFRAME
F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_NOPARENTNOTIFY
member.summary: The child window created with this style does not send the WM_PARENTNOTIFY message to its parent window when it is created or destroyed.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_TOPMOST
member.summary: The window should be placed above all non-topmost windows and should stay above them, even when the window is deactivated. To add or remove this style, use the SetWindowPos function.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_ACCEPTFILES
member.summary: The window accepts drag-drop files.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_TRANSPARENT
member.summary: The window should not be painted until siblings beneath the window (that were created by the same thread) have been painted. The window appears transparent because the bits of underlying sibling windows have already been painted. To achieve transparency without these restrictions, use the SetWindowRgn function.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_MDICHILD
member.summary: The window is a MDI child window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_TOOLWINDOW
member.summary: The window is intended to be used as a floating toolbar. A tool window has a title bar that is shorter than a normal title bar, and the window title is drawn using a smaller font. A tool window does not appear in the taskbar or in the dialog that appears when the user presses ALT+TAB. If a tool window has a system menu, its icon is not displayed on the title bar. However, you can display the system menu by right-clicking or by typing ALT+SPACE.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_WINDOWEDGE
member.summary: The window has a border with a raised edge.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_CLIENTEDGE
member.summary: The window has a border with a sunken edge.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP
member.summary: The title bar of the window includes a question mark. When the user clicks the question mark, the cursor changes to a question mark with a pointer. If the user then clicks a child window, the child receives a WM_HELP message. The child window should pass the message to the parent window procedure, which should call the WinHelp function using the HELP_WM_HELP command. The Help application displays a pop-up window that typically contains help for the child window. WS_EX_CONTEXTHELP cannot be used with the WS_MAXIMIZEBOX or WS_MINIMIZEBOX styles.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_RIGHT
member.summary: The window has generic "right-aligned" properties. This depends on the window class. This style has an effect only if the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment; otherwise, the style is ignored. Using the WS_EX_RIGHT style for static or edit controls has the same effect as using the SS_RIGHT or ES_RIGHT style, respectively. Using this style with button controls has the same effect as using BS_RIGHT and BS_RIGHTBUTTON styles.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_LEFT
member.summary: The window has generic left-aligned properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_RTLREADING
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading-order alignment, the window text is displayed using right-to-left reading-order properties. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_LTRREADING
member.summary: The window text is displayed using left-to-right reading-order properties. This is the default.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_LEFTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading order alignment, the vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the left of the client area. For other languages, the style is ignored.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_RIGHTSCROLLBAR
member.summary: The vertical scroll bar (if present) is to the right of the client area. This is the default.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_CONTROLPARENT
member.summary: The window itself contains child windows that should take part in dialog box navigation. If this style is specified, the dialog manager recurses into children of this window when performing navigation operations such as handling the TAB key, an arrow key, or a keyboard mnemonic.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_STATICEDGE
member.summary: The window has a three-dimensional border style intended to be used for items that do not accept user input.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_APPWINDOW
member.summary: Forces a top-level window onto the taskbar when the window is visible.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_OVERLAPPEDWINDOW
member.summary: The window is an overlapped window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_PALETTEWINDOW
member.summary: The window is palette window, which is a modeless dialog box that presents an array of commands.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_LAYERED
member.summary: The window is a layered window. This style cannot be used if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC. Windows 8: The WS_EX_LAYERED style is supported for top-level windows and child windows. Previous Windows versions support WS_EX_LAYERED only for top-level windows.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_NOINHERITLAYOUT
member.summary: The window does not pass its window layout to its child windows.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_NOREDIRECTIONBITMAP
member.summary: The window does not render to a redirection surface. This is for windows that do not have visible content or that use mechanisms other than surfaces to provide their visual.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_LAYOUTRTL
member.summary: If the shell language is Hebrew, Arabic, or another language that supports reading order alignment, the horizontal origin of the window is on the right edge. Increasing horizontal values advance to the left.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_COMPOSITED
member.summary: Paints all descendants of a window in bottom-to-top painting order using double-buffering. For more information, see Remarks. This cannot be used if the window has a class style of either CS_OWNDC or CS_CLASSDC.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.ExtendedWindowStyleFlags.WS_EX_NOACTIVATE
member.summary: A top-level window created with this style does not become the foreground window when the user clicks it. The system does not bring this window to the foreground when the user minimizes or closes the foreground window. To activate the window, use the SetActiveWindow or SetForegroundWindow function. The window does not appear on the taskbar by default. To force the window to appear on the taskbar, use the WS_EX_APPWINDOW style.

member.summary: The color used to highlight menu items when the menu appears as a flat menu (see SystemParametersInfo). The highlighted menu item is outlined with COLOR_HIGHLIGHT. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SysColorIndexes.ColorMenubar
member.summary: The background color for the menu bar when menus appear as flat menus (see SystemParametersInfo). However, COLOR_MENU continues to specify the background color of the menu popup. Windows 2000: This value is not supported.

member.summary: Sizes the window.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SysCommands.SC_KEYMENU
member.summary: Retrieves the window menu as a result of a keystroke. If the wParam is SC_KEYMENU, lParam contains the character code of the key that is used with the ALT key to display the popup menu. For example, pressing ALT+F to display the File popup will cause a WM_SYSCOMMAND with wParam equal to SC_KEYMENU and lParam equal to 'f'.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SysCommands.SC_SCREENSAVE

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SysCommands.SC_HOTKEY

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SysCommands.SC_DEFAULT

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SysCommands.SC_MONITORPOWER
member.summary: Sets the state of the display. This command supports devices that have power-saving features, such as a battery-powered personal computer. The lParam parameter can have the following values: -1 (the display is powering on) 1 (the display is going to low power) 2 (the display is being shut off)

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXSCREEN
member.summary: Width of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same values obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, HORZRES).

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYSCREEN
member.summary: Height of the screen of the primary display monitor, in pixels. This is the same values obtained by calling GetDeviceCaps as follows: GetDeviceCaps( hdcPrimaryMonitor, VERTRES).

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYVSCROLL
member.summary: Width of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXVSCROLL
member.summary: Height of a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYCAPTION
member.summary: Height of a caption area, in pixels.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXBORDER
member.summary: Width of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CXEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYBORDER
member.summary: Height of a window border, in pixels. This is equivalent to the SM_CYEDGE value for windows with the 3-D look.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXDLGFRAME
member.summary: Thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYDLGFRAME
member.summary: Thickness of the frame around the perimeter of a window that has a caption but is not sizable, in pixels. SM_CXFIXEDFRAME is the height of the horizontal border and SM_CYFIXEDFRAME is the width of the vertical border.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYVTHUMB
member.summary: Height of the thumb box in a vertical scroll bar, in pixels

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXHTHUMB
member.summary: Width of the thumb box in a horizontal scroll bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXICON
member.summary: Default width of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions specified by SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYICON
member.summary: Default height of an icon, in pixels. The LoadIcon function can load only icons with the dimensions SM_CXICON and SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXCURSOR
member.summary: Width of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYCURSOR
member.summary: Height of a cursor, in pixels. The system cannot create cursors of other sizes.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENU
member.summary: Height of a single-line menu bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXFULLSCREEN
member.summary: Width of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYFULLSCREEN
member.summary: Height of the client area for a full-screen window on the primary display monitor, in pixels. To get the coordinates of the portion of the screen not obscured by the system taskbar or by application desktop toolbars, call the SystemParametersInfo function with the SPI_GETWORKAREA value.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYKANJIWINDOW

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYMIN

member.summary: Width of a button in a window's caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYSIZE
member.summary: Height of a button in a window's caption or title bar, in pixels.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXFRAME
member.summary: Thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. SM_CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and SM_CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYFRAME
member.summary: Thickness of the sizing border around the perimeter of a window that can be resized, in pixels. SM_CXSIZEFRAME is the width of the horizontal border, and SM_CYSIZEFRAME is the height of the vertical border.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXMINTRACK
member.summary: Minimum tracking width of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYMINTRACK
member.summary: Minimum tracking height of a window, in pixels. The user cannot drag the window frame to a size smaller than these dimensions. A window can override this value by processing the WM_GETMINMAXINFO message

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXDOUBLECLK
member.summary: Width of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYDOUBLECLK
member.summary: Height of the rectangle around the location of a first click in a double-click sequence, in pixels. The second click must occur within the rectangle defined by SM_CXDOUBLECLK and SM_CYDOUBLECLK for the system to consider the two clicks a double-click. (The two clicks must also occur within a specified time.)

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CXICONSPACING

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYICONSPACING
member.summary: Height of a grid cell for items in large icon view, in pixels. Each item fits into a rectangle of size SM_CXICONSPACING by SM_CYICONSPACING when arranged. This value is always greater than or equal to SM_CYICON.

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_DBCSENABLED

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYSMICON

member.name: F:Dapplo.Windows.User32.Enums.SystemMetric.SM_CYMENUSIZE

member.summary: Width of a minimized window, in pixels.
